blog.name: pinofanimate
blog.title: PINOF Animate!
blog.description: A Dan and Phil animation project! Animators from around the world will come together to make a tribute to the PINOF series.

summary: Welcome to PINOF Animate! This is a fan-made project that features animations from various artists from around the world to...
caption:
Welcome to PINOF Animate! This is a fan-made project that features animations from various artists from around the world to recreate, shot by shot, PINOF 9. The reason for this project is to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the PINOF series, and to show @danielhowell and @amazingphil​ our love and support.

Hope you enjoy the result! And make sure to stay until after the credits to see a few extras :)

Credits under the cut

CREDITS:

Produced and Edited by
TwilightCiel

Thumbnail  by
gryphll

ILLUSTRATORS
aum45_pastel
Grant
gryphll
Kristin Duran
Krystellen
Nikorii
nopeemi
Ahalfdecentartist | Winnie | Yaweinni

ANIMATORS
adzie | imakedoodleslol
Alanna Harlow
Azu
cloudydip
CJoana
Dan
Dora
Gilove2dance
gryphll
Hang
Hannah Hoffman
Hayley

kinocharlley
lilydzieart
loz
Lulu
maddie!

Marki
max
Misha
みや(MIYA)
Nikoleta Pante

nopeemi
Pia

Sabrina Schultz
Siv
Spence
TwilightCiel
Usagi
Vic

MUSIC
Theme for Harold var 2  (Incompetech)
Pixel Peeker Polka - slower (Incompetech)

tags: i'm not sure this was just a little prompt from one of my writing books so i rolled with it
title: leaves my body glowing
body:
Although it was small in comparison to other national phenomenons, the sudden pattern in the cornfield brought hundreds of spectators to the farm to overlook the crop circles. Phil didn’t mind too much, after a while the company of just his animals wasn’t enough to ease his instinctual needs.

Before the abnormalities began, it was only him and his livestock, no one else in their little cluster. Everyday he would ride behind the cattle on his quarter horse mare, herding them over the town bridge – which had a great view of the entirety of his farm – to the best grasslands. But just last week, on the daily ride home, he could have sworn he saw a silver dome shape gleaming in the light of the sunset, coming from just over the first hill, a small ways beyond the barn. He shook his head and chalked it up to a long day of work, assuring himself that he’d finish the rest of the chores quickly so he could go to sleep early tonight. He put the cows back, remembering to say goodnight to all ten, and went to give Amber her grain, planning to check out the mirage his tired brain conjured up when she’d settled.

Phil did up the latch on the barn door and started the walk out back. It was a bit of a journey, but he wouldn’t risk riding out there in case Amber got spooked. He certainly didn’t need a broken neck from being thrown. Coming over the crest of the hill, Phil thought he saw a figure dash through an opening in the crops to the left of his peripheral.

“Who’s there?” He shouted, cursing himself for not bringing some form of defense. It was probably just some ratty criminal on the run, hiding out in his fields from the law. “I said: who’s there?” Phil called again. He needed to get a good look at their face in case he had to go in to pick them out of a lineup after they were detained. Phil waited for a moment without seeing anything before he turned around to head home, deciding the criminal ran off again. He spun on his heel, jumping three feet in the air as he almost walked right into a man who looked to be just a bit younger than Phil. In the lingering sunlight, Phil found the man had curly brown hair, and gleaming brown eyes that stared right back at him – not in a creepy way, but with great interest and curiosity. After a few stuttering breaths, Phil calmed down, putting his hand over his heart to assess its pounding rhythm.

“Uh, hi,” he choked out, the man simply staring back at him in silence. As Phil awkwardly studied him in return, he was convinced he saw the man’s brown eyes changing color. They turned from golden brown to a blue gray, then a muted purple – like the aurora borealis –  finally settling on brown once more. Phil’s brain assured himself that it wasn’t possible for eyes to naturally be that color. Time passed, and the man kept staring at Phil, seemingly unblinking. Phil was silently freaking out. He assumed they must be in between a language barrier or else the man surely would have said something by now, so he motioned to himself slowly.

“I’m Phil,” he enunciated, speaking slowly and trying for a warm tone. He wasn’t sure if the man would respond, so he held his hand out as a peace offering. Phil watched as the man’s eyes darted from Phil’s hand to his face and back, panicky, but almost as if they were also searching for something. Phil shrugged and withdrew his hand to rest at his side. He took one final look into the field for any source of explanation as to where the trespasser came from.

“Suit yourself,” He grumbled, withdrawing from the encounter to walk back to his house, hoping the man would run off to wherever he came from and leave him be. The guy really didn’t look like a psychopath. Not that one could necessarily model the part on appearance alone, but that’s beside the point. Phil made it to the backdoor a while later. He hadn’t heard anything else on the way back, so he figured he was in the clear from any more potential disturbances. In the reflection of the door’s window, he almost imagined another figure behind him. He turned around cautiously, and sure enough, the weird guy was there. Except now, his hair looked darker under the light of the back porch, and his skin was glowing. And not like a happy glow. Purple, like his eyes had once been.

“Uh,” Phil stuttered as he was watched expectantly. “Do you want to come in?” He offered, mentally punching himself. This guy was Cirque-Du-Soleil levels of freaky and Phil just asked him to enter his home. What’s next, tea and family game night? Although he had another puzzled look about him, the man (thing?) gave a jerky head nod and watched Phil again. Phil opened the screen door, waiting for man to go in. When he didn’t enter first, Phill sighed and went in, clumsily holding the door as the man right on his heels. Literally. He had almost no elbow room. This was by far the weirdest and most awkward Phil had ever felt. Closing the door behind them, he attempted to turn around, coming to a stop a mere few inches from the other man’s face. And even though he should probably pull back and apologize, he was convinced that the man’s eyes were changing color – blue to gray, then purple, with a hint of yellow. Phil was frozen still and studying the man once more, but he jerked back a step when his brain caught up to the anomaly in front of him.

“Do you have a name?” He asked, even somewhat knowing that he wouldn’t get an answer. The man surprised him once more, though, as he opened his mouth to speak.

What came out was more of a garbled squawk, though. Phil had to hold back a laugh, knowing it would be rude to make fun of his guest.

“I don’t think we speak the same language,” he began, “but I caught a bit of a ‘D’ sound in there so we’ll go off that. How about -” he broke off, looking around his kitchen for something. He spotted an empty can on the counter. “Dan?” The man preened at that, a bright pink hue working its way up his freckled neck. There was a softness in his eyes, too. Phil couldn’t stop looking at them, the color changes reminding him of paint washing off a brush, all the shades mixing and bleeding together. Besides his eyes and gleaming skin, Phil noticed Dan was wearing normal clothes, like his – baggy jeans and a loose cotton tee, but no shoes. His feet were awfully clean for being barefoot in the dirt for however long he must have been wandering around in Phil’s fields. Phil really needed to figure out what was going on. He tried to gesture for Dan to go sit on the couch in the living room, deciding to show him what he meant instead when Dan didn’t move from beside him. Immediately after Phil sat, Dan was next to him again, pressed right up against his side. Desperately, Phil tried to think of what to say, the silence gradually suffocating his brain.

Before Phil could speak, Dan pulled at his hand from where it rested on his knee. Phil let him, merely a spectator as Dan too his hand and turned it palm up. He kept his own eyes trained on Phil, assessing him for something, but Phil was too distracted to find out what. Dan’s hand was unusually soft, almost silk-like, and as he looked on longer, the skin on his fingertips began to shift into the color of the night sky. Now Phil knew he was losing his mind, no doubt about it. Phil observed as the colors took over Dan’s whole hand, resembling the galaxy enough that Phil could make out little planets and comets. It was astonishing. The galaxy kept growing bigger, traversing up Dan’s arm, and even starting to appear on the other. Phil sensed himself smiling in awe, his unoccupied hand almost reaching out to touch Dan’s, but stopping just before, fearful that he might muck up something so beautiful.

Sooner than he’d like, the galaxies started to fade back down Dan’s arm and onto his hand, finally ending to rest on his fingertips like polish. Dan smiled oddly at Phil. Phil shook his head, blown away but whatever it was that just happened. He’d never seen anything like Dan, and now, selfishly, he wanted to keep him here and solve the puzzle of this wonderfully alien mystery.

“Who’s there?” He shouted, cursing himself for not bringing some form of defense. It was probably just some ratty criminal on the run, hiding out in his fields from the law. “I said: who’s there?” Phil called again. He needed to get a good look at their face in case he had to go in to pick them out of a lineup after they were detained. Phil waited for a moment without seeing anything before he turned around to head home, deciding the criminal ran off again. He spun on his heel, jumping three feet in the air as he almost walked right into a man who looked to be just a bit younger than Phil. In the lingering sunlight, Phil found the man had curly brown hair, and gleaming brown eyes that stared right back at him – not in a creepy way, but with great interest and curiosity. After a few stuttering breaths, Phil calmed down, putting his hand over his heart to assess its pounding rhythm.

“Uh, hi,” he choked out, the man simply staring back at him in silence. As Phil awkwardly studied him in return, he was convinced he saw the man’s brown eyes changing color. They turned from golden brown to a blue gray, then a muted purple – like the aurora borealis –  finally settling on brown once more. Phil’s brain assured himself that it wasn’t possible for eyes to naturally be that color. Time passed, and the man kept staring at Phil, seemingly unblinking. Phil was silently freaking out. He assumed they must be in between a language barrier or else the man surely would have said something by now, so he motioned to himself slowly.

“I’m Phil,” he enunciated, speaking slowly and trying for a warm tone. He wasn’t sure if the man would respond, so he held his hand out as a peace offering. Phil watched as the man’s eyes darted from Phil’s hand to his face and back, panicky, but almost as if they were also searching for something. Phil shrugged and withdrew his hand to rest at his side. He took one final look into the field for any source of explanation as to where the trespasser came from.

“Suit yourself,” He grumbled, withdrawing from the encounter to walk back to his house, hoping the man would run off to wherever he came from and leave him be. The guy really didn’t look like a psychopath. Not that one could necessarily model the part on appearance alone, but that’s beside the point. Phil made it to the backdoor a while later. He hadn’t heard anything else on the way back, so he figured he was in the clear from any more potential disturbances. In the reflection of the door’s window, he almost imagined another figure behind him. He turned around cautiously, and sure enough, the weird guy was there. Except now, his hair looked darker under the light of the back porch, and his skin was glowing. And not like a happy glow. Purple, like his eyes had once been.

“Uh,” Phil stuttered as he was watched expectantly. “Do you want to come in?” He offered, mentally punching himself. This guy was Cirque-Du-Soleil levels of freaky and Phil just asked him to enter his home. What’s next, tea and family game night? Although he had another puzzled look about him, the man (thing?) gave a jerky head nod and watched Phil again. Phil opened the screen door, waiting for man to go in. When he didn’t enter first, Phill sighed and went in, clumsily holding the door as the man right on his heels. Literally. He had almost no elbow room. This was by far the weirdest and most awkward Phil had ever felt. Closing the door behind them, he attempted to turn around, coming to a stop a mere few inches from the other man’s face. And even though he should probably pull back and apologize, he was convinced that the man’s eyes were changing color – blue to gray, then purple, with a hint of yellow. Phil was frozen still and studying the man once more, but he jerked back a step when his brain caught up to the anomaly in front of him.

“Do you have a name?” He asked, even somewhat knowing that he wouldn’t get an answer. The man surprised him once more, though, as he opened his mouth to speak.

What came out was more of a garbled squawk, though. Phil had to hold back a laugh, knowing it would be rude to make fun of his guest.

“I don’t think we speak the same language,” he began, “but I caught a bit of a ‘D’ sound in there so we’ll go off that. How about -” he broke off, looking around his kitchen for something. He spotted an empty can on the counter. “Dan?” The man preened at that, a bright pink hue working its way up his freckled neck. There was a softness in his eyes, too. Phil couldn’t stop looking at them, the color changes reminding him of paint washing off a brush, all the shades mixing and bleeding together. Besides his eyes and gleaming skin, Phil noticed Dan was wearing normal clothes, like his – baggy jeans and a loose cotton tee, but no shoes. His feet were awfully clean for being barefoot in the dirt for however long he must have been wandering around in Phil’s fields. Phil really needed to figure out what was going on. He tried to gesture for Dan to go sit on the couch in the living room, deciding to show him what he meant instead when Dan didn’t move from beside him. Immediately after Phil sat, Dan was next to him again, pressed right up against his side. Desperately, Phil tried to think of what to say, the silence gradually suffocating his brain.

Before Phil could speak, Dan pulled at his hand from where it rested on his knee. Phil let him, merely a spectator as Dan too his hand and turned it palm up. He kept his own eyes trained on Phil, assessing him for something, but Phil was too distracted to find out what. Dan’s hand was unusually soft, almost silk-like, and as he looked on longer, the skin on his fingertips began to shift into the color of the night sky. Now Phil knew he was losing his mind, no doubt about it. Phil observed as the colors took over Dan’s whole hand, resembling the galaxy enough that Phil could make out little planets and comets. It was astonishing. The galaxy kept growing bigger, traversing up Dan’s arm, and even starting to appear on the other. Phil sensed himself smiling in awe, his unoccupied hand almost reaching out to touch Dan’s, but stopping just before, fearful that he might muck up something so beautiful.

Sooner than he’d like, the galaxies started to fade back down Dan’s arm and onto his hand, finally ending to rest on his fingertips like polish. Dan smiled oddly at Phil. Phil shook his head, blown away but whatever it was that just happened. He’d never seen anything like Dan, and now, selfishly, he wanted to keep him here and solve the puzzle of this wonderfully alien mystery.
trail.content:
Although it was small in comparison to other national phenomenons, the sudden pattern in the cornfield brought hundreds of spectators to the farm to overlook the crop circles. Phil didn’t mind too much, after a while the company of just his animals wasn’t enough to ease his instinctual needs.

Before the abnormalities began, it was only him and his livestock, no one else in their little cluster. Everyday he would ride behind the cattle on his quarter horse mare, herding them over the town bridge – which had a great view of the entirety of his farm – to the best grasslands. But just last week, on the daily ride home, he could have sworn he saw a silver dome shape gleaming in the light of the sunset, coming from just over the first hill, a small ways beyond the barn. He shook his head and chalked it up to a long day of work, assuring himself that he’d finish the rest of the chores quickly so he could go to sleep early tonight. He put the cows back, remembering to say goodnight to all ten, and went to give Amber her grain, planning to check out the mirage his tired brain conjured up when she’d settled.

Phil did up the latch on the barn door and started the walk out back. It was a bit of a journey, but he wouldn’t risk riding out there in case Amber got spooked. He certainly didn’t need a broken neck from being thrown. Coming over the crest of the hill, Phil thought he saw a figure dash through an opening in the crops to the left of his peripheral.

“Who’s there?” He shouted, cursing himself for not bringing some form of defense. It was probably just some ratty criminal on the run, hiding out in his fields from the law. “I said: who’s there?” Phil called again. He assumed they must be in between a language barrier or else the man surely would have said something by now, so he motioned to himself slowly.

“I’m Phil,” he enunciated, speaking slowly and trying for a warm tone. He wasn’t sure if the man would respond, so he held his hand out as a peace offering. Phil watched as the man’s eyes darted from Phil’s hand to his face and back, panicky, but almost as if they were also searching for something. Phil shrugged and withdrew his hand to rest at his side. He took one final look into the field for any source of explanation as to where the trespasser came from.

“Suit yourself,” He grumbled, withdrawing from the encounter to walk back to his house, hoping the man would run off to wherever he came from and leave him be. The guy really didn’t look like a psychopath. Not that one could necessarily model the part on appearance alone, but that’s beside the point. Phil made it to the backdoor a while later. He hadn’t heard anything else on the way back, so he figured he was in the clear from any more potential disturbances. In the reflection of the door’s window, he almost imagined another figure behind him. He turned around cautiously, and sure enough, the weird guy was there. Except now, his hair looked darker under the light of the back porch, and his skin was glowing. And not like a happy glow. Purple, like his eyes had once been.

“Uh,” Phil stuttered as he was watched expectantly. “Do you want to come in?” He offered, mentally punching himself. This guy was Cirque-Du-Soleil levels of freaky and Phil just asked him to enter his home. What’s next, tea and family game night? Although he had another puzzled look about him, the man (thing?) gave a jerky head nod and watched Phil again. Phil opened the screen door, waiting for man to go in. When he didn’t enter first, Phill sighed and went in, clumsily holding the door as the man right on his heels. Literally. He had almost no elbow room. This was by far the weirdest and most awkward Phil had ever felt. Closing the door behind them, he attempted to turn around, coming to a stop a mere few inches from the other man’s face. And even though he should probably pull back and apologize, he was convinced that the man’s eyes were changing color – blue to gray, then purple, with a hint of yellow. Phil was frozen still and studying the man once more, but he jerked back a step when his brain caught up to the anomaly in front of him.

“Do you have a name?” He asked, even somewhat knowing that he wouldn’t get an answer. The man surprised him once more, though, as he opened his mouth to speak.

What came out was more of a garbled squawk, though. Phil had to hold back a laugh, knowing it would be rude to make fun of his guest.

“I don’t think we speak the same language,” he began, “but I caught a bit of a ‘D’ sound in there so we’ll go off that. How about -” he broke off, looking around his kitchen for something. He spotted an empty can on the counter. “Dan?” The man preened at that, a bright pink hue working its way up his freckled neck. There was a softness in his eyes, too.
